A law of composition on a set $M$ is commutative if $ab = ba$ for all elements $a, b \in M$.

A family (x_i)_{i in I} of elements of an A-module M is called free or linearly independent if from an equation sum_{i in I} a_i x_i = 0 with coefficients a_i in A we can conclude that a_i = 0 for all i in I. A free system of generators will also be referred to as a basis.
Does the concept of a/an Commutative Law need to be defined for a definition of a/an Free system of generators (basis) to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of a free system of generators (basis) for an A-module M involves the idea that a set of elements (x_i)_{i in I} is linearly independent, meaning that any linear combination of these elements that equals zero implies that all the coefficients of the combination must be zero. This definition focuses on the properties of linear independence and does not inherently require any operation within the set M to be commutative.

On the other hand, the commutative law pertains to a binary operation on a set being commutative, that is, the operation yields the same result regardless of the order of the operands. This law is relevant in contexts where the order of operations affects the outcome.

In the context of defining a free system of generators, the commutative law is not directly relevant. The definition of a basis does not depend on the commutativity of any operations within the module M but rather on the concept of linear independence of the generators. Therefore, the commutative law does not need to be defined or assumed for the definition of a free system of generators to make sense.
